Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 2018 International Symposium on Computer Architecture (ISCA)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Symposium on Computer Architecture (ISCA) is a flagship conference in the area of computer architecture. The 2018 annual conference, along with several collocated workshops on related topics, will take place in Los Angeles, CA. The conference is an important venue for reporting current research on important topics addressing grand challenges in computing resulting, e.g., from the impending Moore's law slowdown of performance of computing machines. The topic is the main focus of the program area of the SHF cluster of the CISE/CCF division at NSF, and thus ISCA is a venue where major results of research supported by the program gets presented, discussed, debated and future direction of research are charted.

This award will support approximately 100 students by defraying part of their cost for travel and attendance for ISCA 2018. Since attendance to ISCA can be viewed as an integral part of computer systems design education and research in academia, the proposal would go a long way towards supporting workforce development in the important area information technology. The conference is also attended by leading researchers from technology companies (e.g., IBM, Intel, Microsoft etc.), and provides a basis for interaction between academia and industry, thus potentially enhancing technology transfer on problems of current and future societal needs. The grants to 100 students seek to enhance the diversity of the attendees, thus maintain a balance between underrepresented and other groups among the participants supported from the grant. Upon completion of the project, the awardee will submit a report to NSF with details of student experiences and the details of the expenditures towards supporting them to attend the conference and workshops collocated with it.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Symposium on Computer Architecture (ISCA) is a premier forum for research on computer architecture, the hardware/software interface, and systems architecture. This project supported this flagship conference by providing travel grant support for students to attend the ISCA conference in June 2018 in Los Angeles, USA.

The NSF grant money was used to support students who are enrolled in an US university. We used multi-tier supporting structure where priority was given to underrepresented groups of students, followed by student authors of accepted conference and workshop papers, and students who could not ordinarily attend, such as those without travel support from their advisor. Students were especially encouraged to submit work in progress to and attend the co-located workshops. The availability of travel support was announced through the conference website soon after the official acceptance of this proposal.

The grant supported 45 participants.  Additionally 29 of the 45 recipients were from groups underrepresented in STEM.  It is worth highlighting that this year's travel award process focused heavily on increasing attendance from underrepresented groups, and so we had an unprecedented number of awardees from this category. We found that engaging with programs like CRAW, Women in Computer Architecture, etc., greatly helped in reaching out to these broad group of students.

ISCA 2018 was also the venue for the 2017 Turing Award lecture and reception, which is the most prestigious award in computer science and engineering. Students had the unique opportunity to listen and to be inspired by the technical lecture from the Turing award winners.
